head.title: John Thompson III Gets Princeton Job

hedline.hl1: John Thompson III Gets Princeton Job

abstract.p: John Thompson III is named coach of Princeton men's basketball team (S)

block.p: John Thompson III was named coach of the Princeton men's basketball team yesterday, following the career path of his father, who built Georgetown into a basketball power. The appointment came on the same day Bill Carmody left to become coach of Northwestern.
It will be the first head coaching job for Thompson, 34. He has been an assistant coach the past five years at Princeton under Pete Carril and Carmody.

John Thompson III was named coach of the Princeton men's basketball team yesterday, following the career path of his father, who built Georgetown into a basketball power. The appointment came on the same day Bill Carmody left to become coach of Northwestern.
It will be the first head coaching job for Thompson, 34. He has been an assistant coach the past five years at Princeton under Pete Carril and Carmody.

Thompson has three starters returning from a team that was 19-11 last season, losing in the first round of the National Invitation Tournament to Penn State. But the Tigers sustained a major loss a little more than a week ago when the unanimous All-Ivy League center Chris Young signed a baseball contract with the Pittsburgh Pirates. The Ivy League does not allow athletes who sign a professional contract in one sport to play in another.
Thompson, a former Princeton player, graduated in 1988. A forward, Thompson was co-captain in his senior year and shared the team most valuable player award as the Tigers went 17-9. (AP)
CARMODY GOES TO NORTHWESTERN: After 18 years at Princeton, the last four as head coach, Bill Carmody was named yesterday as the coach at Northwestern, a team that was 5-25 last season.

Winning as often as he did at Princeton, where he was 92-25 in four seasons after replacing Pete Carril, will not be easy. Instead of Dartmouth and Cornell, he will be going against Michigan State and Indiana.
Northwestern did not win a game in the Big Ten last season and now must adjust to a new coach after the resignation of Kevin O'Neill, who left last week to become an assistant with the Knicks.
I come in with my eyes open, Carmody said. I know it's going to be a rough situation.

There is an impression that Princeton still wins by holding the ball with a deliberate style that is low scoring and frustrating for defenses. But Carmody says his teams play a style that is suited to their talent, not a system. He quickly moved to convince some of Northwestern's players.

The offense is very free and open and flowing, he said. I showed some of the players a tape from Princeton. We're not holding the ball; that's a perception. It's not a dictatorship. The players will tell you how to play. It's basketball. Guard your man, make shots and let's go. (AP)

CORNELL HIRES A PENN ASSISTANT: Cornell University named Steve Donahue as its new coach, handing him a program that finished last in the Ivy League last season. Donahue has been an assistant at the University of Pennsylvania for the past 10 years.
Donahue replaces Scott Thompson, who resigned in July after four years as coach. Thompson, who has colon cancer, took another position within the university's athletic department. (Bloomberg News)
